title: Trek Madone vs Domane: The best Trek road bike in 2024
content:
Cyclist
Trek Madone vs Domane: The best Trek road bike in 2024

A few months ago, you’d have had three Trek road bikes to choose from. But the launch of the eighth generation of the Trek Madone has seen the bike shed so much weight that Trek is discontinuing its Emonda lightweight platform, as it says that the new Madone is as light as the Emonda but as aero as the previous generation Madone.

That leaves just two Trek road bike platforms, the race-oriented Madone and the endurance and all-road-focussed Domane. Both are offered in a range of specs, with the premium models exceeding £10,000 in price.

There are more affordable options lower down the tree though. The Madone sticks to carbon, but the Domane offers an alloy frame option that keeps entry-level prices low. There’s even a rim brake Domane AL available still.

Here, we’ll run through key aspects of the Domane and Madone’s specs and features, then we’ll document all the specs available and help you to choose between the Trek Domane and the Trek Madone, if you’re looking at a Trek for your next bike purchase.

Trek Madone vs Domane: Key features at a glance

Trek Madone

  • Generation 8 is both aero and low in weight
  • Two carbon frame grades: OCLV 9, OCLV 5
  • Trek Race Geometry
  • Aero bar/stem on SLR specs
  • 32mm tyre clearance

Trek Domane

  • Two carbon and one alloy frame options
  • Internal down tube storage
  • Trek Endurance Geometry
  • Mudguard mounts
  • 38mm tyre clearance, 35mm with mudguards

Trek Domane SLR review

Trek Madone vs Domane: aerodynamics

The Madone platform has focussed on aerodynamics for almost ten years. In the past, that’s led to some chunky-looking bikes with weights to match. 

That changed with the Gen 7 Madone, which, although retaining quite a chunky profile, shed around 300g from its frame weight, thanks in large part to the abandonment of the IsoSpeed rear decoupler.

The Gen 8 Madone has taken that a stage further, losing yet another 320g from the top spec frame, while retaining similar aerodynamic performance to the Gen 7 model. Its IsoFlow seat tube is a little slimmer than that of its predecessor, but there are other aero gains that make up for this.

Although it doesn’t focus on aerodynamics, the Domane too has aero tube profiles. The latest version is another Trek bike that has lost a claimed 300g from its predecessor.

Trek Madone vs Domane: comfort

Ride comfort is the Domane’s calling card. As an endurance bike, it’s designed to place you more upright, which can help avoid aches and pains in the back, shoulders, arms and neck.

That’s augmented by the inclusion of rear IsoSpeed, which decouples the seatpost from the top tube, helping to add more compliance. 

Trek has been progressively withdrawing from IsoSpeed; the current generation Domane has the system just in the rear and it’s now non-adjustable, while its predecessor had adjustable rear IsoSpeed as well as front IsoSpeed.

One reason is the system’s weight. Trek cited the removal of adjustable IsoSpeed as a major factor in the 300g weight loss when it moved from the Gen 6 to the Gen 7 Madone. It also claimed that few riders were making use of the system’s adjustability.

Don’t think that the latest Gen 8 Madone is an uncomfortable bike. Although its Trek Race Geometry (a successor to its H1.5 geometry on its previous generation race bikes) is more aggressive than the Domane, Trek claims that it’s made the latest Madone 80 percent more compliant than its predecessor. 

Nevertheless, the Madone Gen 8 is a race bike, so the focus is on speed and performance, rather than ride comfort.

Tyres are a major contributor to road smoothing and here too the Domane has the advantage, with 38mm tyre clearance rather than the Madone’s still reasonably generous 32mm.

Trek Madone vs Domane: weight

Aero race bikes used to be heavy, but they’ve gradually slimmed down. The Madone Gen 8 is no exception, with full bike weights as low as 7kg for the top spec model. That’s allowed Trek to kill off the Emonda, its lightweight bike platform. In contrast, we weighed the top spec of the Gen 6 Madone at 7.6kg when we reviewed it in 2019.

When compared to the Domane, there’s not a huge difference. We weighed the mid-range Domane SLR 7 eTap at 8.2kg and Trek claims a weight of 7.3kg for the top spec Domane SLR 9 bike. Not bad for an endurance bike with 32mm tyres and a hole in its downtube and not a huge amount greater than the Madone, so bike weight isn’t a major differentiator.

Trek Madone vs Domane: sizing

For a wide range of frame size options, the Domane wins out, with nine sizes available from 44 up to 62. 

Don’t think that the Madone’s six sizes will make it difficult to find your size though. Although Trek eliminated two sizes available in the Gen 7 bike when it introduced the Gen 8 Madone, it says that this reduces overlaps between sizes, making it easier to choose your frame size if you’re at the cusp between two.

Trek claims that, despite its smaller number of frame sizes, the Madone will accommodate riders between 143cm and 213cm tall, in contrast to the Domane’s 150cm to 195cm. 

Trek Madone vs Domane: geometry

Trek calls the Madone Gen 8’s geometry Trek Race Geometry. It’s only marginally different from the H1.5 geometry of the previous generation Madone. In the past, Trek offered its race bikes in either H1 or H2 geometry, with H1 being more aggressive, for racers, and H2 being a little more upright, for Joe Average.

It pared this down to H1.5 only, as pros generally became less focussed on super-aggressive ride positions. This also avoided the need to produce two sets of framesets, and Trek has now rebranded the H1.5 geo as Trek Race. 

The Domane, meanwhile, has Trek Endurance Geometry. As you’d expect, this is more relaxed for more even weight distribution and stability. 

Trek’s different sizing for the Madone and Domane make numeric comparisons difficult. There are the typical differences between a race and an endurance bike though: shorter and steeper head tube, shorter chainstays and wheelbase, longer reach and lower stack on the Madone versus the Domane.

Trek Madone vs Domane: frame grades

Both the Madone and the Domane are available in two grades of carbon fibre. The higher spec bikes use the SLR platform, while lower specs sit on the SL platform. The Domane adds an alloy AL version.

Trek calls its carbon frame tech OCLV for optimum compaction-low void. It’s an acronym that it’s been using since its first carbon frames, with increments in the OCLV number.

So the latest Madone SLR has OCLV 900 carbon, while the Domane SLR has OCLV 800 carbon. The Madone SL and Domane SL, meanwhile, are both fabricated with OCLV 500 carbon. 

In general, higher numbers mean lower weight, but there’s probably not a lot to differentiate OCLV 900 and OCLV 800. Any differences in frame weight and stiffness are more down to frame design. 

Trek Madone vs Domane: gearing and groupsets

Endurance bikes generally offer lower gearing and wider spreads than race bikes and the Domane is no exception. All specs are equipped with a 50/34t compact crankset or its SRAM equivalent, 46/33t. All get a wide-range cassette: 11-34t or 11-32t for Shimano or 10-33t or 10-36t for SRAM. 

The Domane offers a wide range of Shimano groupsets, from 12-speed Dura-Ace to 8-speed Claris. SRAM groupsets are all 12-speed wireless and range from the latest SRAM Red AXS, via Force AXS to Rival AXS.

The Madone, meanwhile, is equipped with higher ratios, with Shimano bikes having a semi-compact 52/36t crankset or SRAM 48/35t. Cassettes are narrower range too on higher spec bikes, with 11-30t on Shimano and 10-33t on SRAM spec bikes, although an 11-34t or 10-36t feature lower down the range.

The lowest Shimano spec Madone has 12-speed 105 mechanical shifting, while SRAM specs include a Rival AXS option.

The Madone is designed for pro-level racing and can also accommodate larger chainrings to satisfy the pros: a 56/43t double or a 54t 1x. 

The carbon Domane, because of its tyre clearance, is limited to a 52/36t maximum and the alloy bike to 50/34t. As with its predecessor, the Domane can be configured for 1x though, with a 48t maximum chainring. 

Lizzie Deignan won the inaugural Paris-Roubaix Femmes in 2021 on a Domane equipped with a 1x groupset and Elisa Longo Borghini repeated the feat on a 1x bike in 2022. 

Trek Madone vs Domane: handlebars

Another differentiator between the Madone and the Domane is the handlebars. 

Even the highest spec Domane SLR models are equipped with a separate bar and stem, offering adjustability. The Bontrager Pro ISoCore VR-SF bar is carbon and includes Trek’s IsoCore tech, which is claimed to reduce road vibration by 20 percent. You can add under-bar tape pads to make things even smoother. There’s a 4 degree flare to the drops.

Domane SL and higher spec Domane AL models swap to the Bontrager Elite IsoZone VR-SF alloy bar, while there’s another alloy bar on the lower spec AL models.

The Madone SLR, meanwhile, has a single piece bar/stem. Its carbon Trek Aero RSL Road bar has a slightly deeper section to the tops than the Gen 7 Madone’s bar/stem. Trek says that its wind tunnel testing shows that this is more aero than the Madone 7’s as it deflects the wind more effectively from the rider’s legs. 

The Madone’s bar/stem also has a more pronounced 6 degree flare than the Domane’s bars. This places the rider’s hands 3cm closer together on the tops than in the drops, providing a more aero ride position while still offering control when descending.

The SL grade Madones have a two-piece bar and stem, with the carbon bars also designed with aero tops and a flare.

Trek Madone vs Domane: ranges compared

Next, we’ll run through all the specs available for the Madone and the Domane, along with their prices.

Trek Madone bike range

The Madone Gen 8 is offered in four SLR specs with the higher grade 900 Series OCLV carbon and another four SL specs with OCLV 500 grade carbon. As of July 2024, you can also still buy the Gen 7 Madone, which we’ve not covered here.

Madone SLR 9 AXS Gen 8

  • Frame/fork: Madone Gen 8 900 Series OCLV Carbon
  • Handlebars: Trek Aero RSL Road one-piece carbon
  • Groupset: SRAM Red AXS 12-speed, 48/35t, 10-33t
  • Power meter: SRAM Red
  • Wheels: Bontrager Aeolus RSL 51 carbon
  • Saddle: Bontrager Aeolus RSL carbon rail 
  • Claimed weight: 7.00kg (size ML) 
  • Price: £12,500

Madone SLR 9 Gen 8

Trek Madone Gen 8 frameset

The Madone frameset is available at both the SLR level with 900 Series carbon, priced at £4,575, and SL level with 500 Series carbon, for £2,750. Trek also sells a variety of previous generation Madone frames.

Trek Domane bike range

With both carbon and alloy options, the Domane offers a lot of choice: there are six SLR and five SL grade carbon bikes, plus another four alloy ones available.

Trek Domane Gen 4 frameset

Trek offers the Domane frameset-only, with the 800 Series OCLV frame sold as either RSL or SLR priced at £4,900. There’s limited stock of previous year frames priced at £4,510. There’s also an SL grade frame built with 500 Series OCLV carbon available at £2,795.

Trek Madone vs Domane: which should you choose?

For the performance road rider, the Madone makes a compelling case. The new bike is more compliant than its predecessor, as well as being lighter. If your budget stretches to the Madone SLR, you’ll get low weight and deep integration. The bike looks the part and its seat tube design turns heads and stands out from the aero bike crowd.

If you’re looking at the Madone SL there’s more adjustability through the two-piece cockpit, so you may find it easier to get comfortable. But, as always, there’s a weight penalty and lower spec components that come with the lower price, so you need to be happy to accept this.

In both cases, you’ll need to enjoy the pro-focused ride position to get the best out of the bike.

The endurance-focussed Domane is likely to prove more comfortable for many riders. If you like to head off-road a bit, the Domane’s all-road credentials offer a less aggressive ride position and significantly wider tyre clearance. Both make for added comfort over the Madone, but may lead to slower progress. The carbon bike’s down tube storage and the mudguard mounts on both framesets make the Domane more of an all-rounder ride too. 

Read our full review of Trek Domane SLR and our Madone Gen 8 launch story for more.
